paragraph: CHAPTER 17. "THE SWEETS ARE POISONED."
tokens: sweets poison

paragraph: "I think, my dear madam," said Mr Everard to Mrs Willis, "that you must believe your pupil.  She has not refused to confess to you from any stubbornness, but from, the simple reason that she has nothing to confess.  I am firmly convinced that things are as she stated them, Mrs Willis.  There is a mystery here which we neither of us can explain, but which we must unravel."
tokens: think dear madam say believe pupil refuse confess stubbornness simple reason have confess convinced thing state be mystery explain unravel

paragraph: Then Mrs Willis and the clergyman had a long and anxious talk together. It lasted for a long time, and some of its results at least were manifest the next morning, for, just before the morning's work began, Mrs Willis came to the large school-room, and, calling Annie Forest to her side, laid her hand on the young girl's shoulder.
tokens: clergyman have long anxious talk last long time result least manifest next morning morning work begin come large school room call side lay hand young girl shoulder

paragraph: "I wish to tell you all, young ladies," she said, "that I completely and absolutely exonerate Annie Forest from having any part in the disgraceful occurrence which took place in this school-room a short time ago.  I allude, of course, as you all know, to the book which was found tampered with in Cecil Temple's desk.  Some one else in this room is guilty, and the mystery has still to be unravelled, and the guilty girl has still to come forward and declare herself.  If she is willing at this moment to come to me here, and fully and freely confess her sin, I will quite forgive her."
tokens: wish tell young lady say exonerate have part disgraceful occurrence take place school room short time allude course know book find tamper desk one else room guilty mystery unravell guilty girl have come declare willing moment come confess sin forgive

paragraph: The head-mistress paused, and, still with her hand on Annie's shoulder, looked anxiously down the long room.  The love and forgiveness which she felt shone in her eyes at this moment.  No girl need have feared aught but tenderness from her just then.
tokens: head mistress pause hand shoulder look long room love forgiveness feel shine eye moment girl fear aught tenderness

paragraph: No one stirred; the moment passed, and a look of sternness returned to the mistress's fine face.
tokens: stirr moment pass look sternness return mistress fine face

paragraph: "No," she said, in her emphatic and clear tones, "the guilty girl prefers waiting until God discovers her sin for her.  My dear, whoever you are, that hour is coming, and you cannot escape from it.  In the meantime, girls, I wish you all to receive Annie Forest as quite innocent.  I believe in her, so does Mr Everard, and so must you. Anyone who treats Miss Forest except as a perfectly innocent and truthful girl incurs my severe displeasure.  My dear, you may return to your seat."
tokens: say emphatic clear tone guilty girl prefer wait discover sin dear hour come escape meantime girl wish receive innocent believe treat innocent truthful girl incur severe displeasure dear return seat

paragraph: Annie, whose face was partly hidden by her curly hair during the greater part of this speech, now tossed it back, and raised her brown eyes with a look of adoration in them to her teacher.  Mrs Willis's face, however, still looked harassed.  Her eyes met Annie's, but no corresponding glow was kindled in them; their glance was just, calm, but cold.
tokens: face hide curly hair great part speech toss raise brown eye look adoration teacher face look harass eye meet corresponding glow kindle glance calm cold

paragraph: The childish heart was conscious of a keen pang of agony, and Annie went back to her lessons without any sense of exultation.
tokens: childish heart conscious keen pang agony go lesson sense exultation

paragraph: The fact was this: Mrs Willis's judgment and reason had been brought round by Mr Everard's words, but in her heart of hearts, almost unknown to herself, there still lingered a doubt of the innocence of her wayward and pretty pupil.  She said over and over to herself that she really now quite believed in Annie Forest, but then would come those whisperings from her pained and sore heart.
tokens: fact judgment reason bring word heart heart unknown linger doubt innocence wayward pretty pupil say believe come whispering pained sore heart

paragraph: "Why did she ever make a caricature of one who has been as a mother to her?  If she made one caricature, could she not make another?  Above all things, if _she_ did not do it, who did?"
tokens: make caricature mother make caricature make thing do

paragraph: Mrs Willis turned away from these unpleasant whispers--she would not let them stay with her, and turned a deaf ear to their ugly words.  She had publicly declared in the school her belief in Annie's absolute innocence, but at the moment when her pupil looked up at her with a world of love and adoration in her gaze, she found to her own infinite distress that she could not give her the old love.
tokens: turn unpleasant whisper let stay turn deaf ear ugly word declare school belief absolute innocence moment pupil look world love adoration gaze find own infinite distress give old love

paragraph: Annie went back to her companions, and bent her head over her lessons, and tried to believe that she was very thankful and very happy, and Cecil Temple managed to whisper a gentle word of congratulation to her, and at the twelve o'clock walk Annie perceived that a few of her school-fellows looked at her with friendly eyes again.  She perceived now that when she went into the play-room she was not absolutely tabooed, and that, if she chose, she might speedily resume her old reign of popularity.  Annie had, to a remarkable extent, the gift of inspiring love, and her old favourites would quickly have flocked back to their sovereign had she so willed it.  It is certainly true that the girls to whom the whole story was known in all its bearings found it difficult to understand how Annie could be innocent; but Mr Everard's and Mrs Willis's assertions were too potent to be disregarded, and most of the girls were only too willing to let the whole affair slide from their minds, and to take back their favourite Annie to their hearts again.
tokens: go companion bend head lesson try believe thankful happy manage whisper gentle word congratulation o'clock walk perceive few school fellow look friendly eye perceive go play room tabooed choose resume old reign popularity remarkable extent gift inspire love old favourite flock sovereign will true girl whole story know bearing find difficult understand innocent assertion potent disregard most girl willing let whole affair slide mind take favourite heart

paragraph: Annie, however, herself did not so will it.  In the play-room she fraternised with the little ones who were alike her friends in adversity and sunshine; she rejected the overtures of her old favourites, but played, and romped, and was merry with the children of the sixth class. She even declined Cecil's invitation to come and sit with her in her drawing-room.
tokens: will play room fraternise little one alike friend adversity sunshine reject overture old favourite play romp merry child sixth class decline invitation come sit draw room

paragraph: "Oh, no," she said, "I hate being still; I am in no humour for a talk. Another time, Cecil, another time.  Now then, Sybil, my beauty, get well on my back, and I'll be the willing dog carrying you round and round the room."
tokens: say hate humour talk time time beauty get back willing dog carry room

paragraph: Annie's face had not a trace of care or anxiety on it, but her eyes would not quite meet Cecil's, and Cecil sighed as she turned away, and her heart, too, began to whisper little, mocking, ugly doubts of poor Annie.
tokens: face have trace care anxiety eye meet sigh turn heart begin whisper little mocking ugly doubt poor

paragraph: During the half-hour before tea that evening Annie was sitting on the floor with a small child in her lap, and two other little ones tumbling about her, when she was startled by a shower of lollipops being poured over her head, down her neck, and into her lap.  She started up and met the sleepy gaze of Susan Drummond.
tokens: half hour tea evening sit floor small child lap other little one tumble startle shower lollipop pour head neck lap start meet sleepy gaze

paragraph: "That's to congratulate you, Miss," said Susan; "you're a very lucky girl to have escaped as you did."
tokens: congratulate say lucky girl escape

paragraph: The little ones began putting Susan's lollipops vigorously into their mouths.  Annie sprang to her feet, shaking the sticky sweetmeats out of her dress on to the floor.
tokens: little one begin put lollipop mouth spring foot shake sticky sweetmeat dress floor

paragraph: "What have I escaped from?" she asked, turning round and facing her companion haughtily.
tokens: escape ask turn face companion

paragraph: "Oh, dear me!" said Susan, stepping back a pace or two.  "I--ah--" stifling a yawn--"I only meant you were very near getting into an ugly scrape.  It's no affair of mine, I'm sure; only I thought you'd like the lollipops."
tokens: dear say step pace stifling yawn mean get ugly scrape affair sure think like lollipop

paragraph: "No, I don't like them at all," said Annie, "nor you either.  Go back to your own companions, please."
tokens: like say go own companion

paragraph: Susan sulkily walked away, and Annie stooped down on the floor.
tokens: walk stoop floor

paragraph: "Now, little darlings," she said, "you mustn't eat those.  No, no, they are not good at all; and they have come from one of Annie's enemies. Most likely they are full of poison.  Let us collect them all, every one, and we will throw them into the fire before we go to tea."
tokens: little darling say eat good come enemy likely full poison let collect one throw fire go tea

paragraph: "But I don't think there's any poison in them," said little Janie West in a regretful tone, as she gobbled down a particularly luscious chocolate cream; "they are all big, and fat, and bursty, and _so_ sweet, Annie, dear."
tokens: think be poison say little regretful tone gobble luscious chocolate cream big fat bursty sweet dear

paragraph: "Never mind, Janie, they are dangerous sweeties all the same.  Come, come, throw them into my apron, and I will run over and toss them into the fire, and we'll have time for a game of leap-frog before tea; oh, fie, Judy," as a very small fat baby began to whimper, "you would not eat the sweeties of one of Annie's enemies."
tokens: mind dangerous sweety same come come throw apron run toss fire have time game leap frog tea fie small fat baby begin whimper eat sweety enemy

paragraph: This last appeal was successful.  The children made a valiant effort, and dashed the tempting goodies into Annie's alpaca apron.  When they were all collected, she marched up the play-room and in the presence of Susan Drummond, Hester Thornton, Cecil Temple, and several more of her school-companions, threw them into the fire.
tokens: last appeal successful child make valiant effort dash tempting goody alpaca apron collect march play room presence several more school companion throw fire

paragraph: "So much for _that_ overture, Miss Drummond," she said, making a mock curtsey, and returning once more to the children.
tokens: much overture say make mock curtsey return more child
